api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: <jats:p>Objectives. The aim of this study was to determine the factor structure of three standardized memory tests: Wechsler Memory Scale‐Revised (WMS‐R), Warrington Recognition Memory Test (WRMT), Doors and People Test (D&P). We investigated whether these different standardized tests of memory are consistent in their evaluation of memory function, and the extent to which these tests} discriminate between different memory functions (e.g. recall/recognition and verbal/non‐verbal memory).</jats:p><jats:p>Design. Fifty patients with selective memory impairment were tested on the WMS‐R, WRMT and D&P.</jats:p><jats:p>Methods. Age‐scaled scores from selective measures of these tests (WMS‐R‐verbal, WMS‐R‐visual, WMS‐R‐delay, WRMT‐words, WRMT‐faces, D&P‐people, D&P‐doors, D&P‐shapes, D&P‐names) were used as input to a factor analysis.</jats:p><jats:p>Results. Maximum likelihood factor analysis yielded a three‐factor solution consistent with a theoretically motivated fractionation of memory function into recall and recognition components. Recognition performance, but not recall performance, showed dissociation into visual and verbal components.</jats:p><jats:p>Conclusions. The WMS‐R, WRMT and D&P are highly consistent in their assessment of memory function. The results of the factor analysis are consistent with a theoretically motivated fractionation of recall and recognition memory. They are also partially consistent with a dissociation between visual and verbal memory function.</jats:p>

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: Factor analysis of three standardized tests of memory in a clinical population

api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: Objectives. The aim of this study was to determine the factor structure of three standardized memory tests: Wechsler Memory Scale-Revised (WMS-R), Warring ton Recognition Memory Test (WRMT), Doors and People Test (D and P). We investigated whether these different standardized tests of memory are consistent in their evaluation of memory function, and the extent to which these tests discriminate between different memory functions (e.g. recall/recognition and verbal/non-verbal memory). Design. Fifty patients with selective memory impairment were tested on the WMS-R, WRMT and D and P. Methods. Age-scaled scores from selective measures of these tests WMS-R-verbal, WMS-R-visual, WMS-R-delay, WRMT-words, WRMT-faces, D and P-people, D and P-doors, D and P-shapes, D and P-names) were used as input to a factor analysis. Results. Maximum likelihood factor analysis yielded a three-factor solution consistent with a theoretically motivated fractionation of memory function into recall and recognition components. Recognition performance, but not recall performance, showed dissociation into visual and verbal components. Conclusions. The WMS-R, WRMT and D and P are highly consistent in their assessment of memory function. The results of the factor analysis are consistent with a theoretically motivated fractionation of recall and recognition memory. They are also partially consistent with a dissociation between visual and verbal memory function.

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: Factor analysis of three standardized tests of memory in a clinical population

api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to determine the factor structure of three standardized memory tests: Wechsler Memory Scale-Revised (WMS-R), Warrington Recognition Memory Test (WRMT), Doors and People Test (D&P). We investigated whether these different standardized tests of memory are consistent in their evaluation of memory function, and the extent to which these tests discriminate between different memory functions (e.g. recall/recognition and verbal/non-verbal memory). DESIGN: Fifty patients with selective memory impairment were tested on the WMS-R, WRMT and D&P. METHODS: Age-scaled scores from selective measures of these tests (WMS-R-verbal, WMS-R-visual, WMS-R-delay, WRMT-words, WRMT-faces, D&P-people, D&P-doors, D&P-shapes, D&P-names) were used as input to a factor analysis. RESULTS: Maximum likelihood factor analysis yielded a three-factor solution consistent with a theoretically motivated fractionation of memory function into recall and recognition components. Recognition performance, but not recall performance, showed dissociation into visual and verbal components. CONCLUSIONS: The WMS-R, WRMT and D&P are highly consistent in their assessment of memory function. The results of the factor analysis are consistent with a theoretically motivated fractionation of recall and recognition memory. They are also partially consistent with a dissociation between visual and verbal memory function.

api:address.api:line: Department of Clinical Neurology, University of Sheffield, UK. N.M.Hunkin@Sheffield.ac.uk

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: Factor analysis of three standardized tests of memory in a clinical population.

api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text:
Objectives

The aim of this study was to determine the factor structure of three standardized memory tests: Wechsler Memory Scale-Revised (WMS-R), Warrington Recognition Memory Test (WRMT), Doors and People Test (D&P). We investigated whether these different standardized tests of memory are consistent in their evaluation of memory function, and the extent to which these tests discriminate between different memory functions (e.g. recall/recognition and verbal/non-verbal memory).

Design

Fifty patients with selective memory impairment were tested on the WMS-R, WRMT and D&P.

Methods

Age-scaled scores from selective measures of these tests (WMS-R-verbal, WMS-R-visual, WMS-R-delay, WRMT-words, WRMT-faces, D&P-people, D&P-doors, D&P-shapes, D&P-names) were used as input to a factor analysis.

Results

Maximum likelihood factor analysis yielded a three-factor solution consistent with a theoretically motivated fractionation of memory function into recall and recognition components. Recognition performance, but not recall performance, showed dissociation into visual and verbal components.

Conclusions

The WMS-R, WRMT and D&P are highly consistent in their assessment of memory function. The results of the factor analysis are consistent with a theoretically motivated fractionation of recall and recognition memory. They are also partially consistent with a dissociation between visual and verbal memory function.

api:address.api:line: Department of Clinical Neurology, University of Sheffield, UK. N.M.Hunkin@Sheffield.ac.uk
